> Perhaps I'm being nitpicky here, but it would probably
> have been more accurate to say that the networks
> learned how to block threats, or how to tie, or how
> not to lose.  Presumably your networks performed very
> poorly against a random opponent (this has been my
> experience in evolving directly against BEST).

Certainly. If I had intended to publish that version it could have used a
lot of work :) That paper focuses more on the method, rather than the
domains. Seriously "solving" tic-tac-toe would require a lot more work.

> Somebody correct me if I'm wrong, but evolution would
> occur even in a randomly-selected, randomly-mated
> population due to simple genetic drift, which would be
> even more pronounced in smaller populations.

I'm a little confused. Are you saying that there is no fitness function?
If fitness evaluation were random, then no, there is not really anything
you can call "evolution" There is genetic drift, but its basically
brownian motion around the centroid of the starting genetic material
(depending on how you structure crossover and mutations).

Joe
